title: Which iPhone models will support 5G, and what models won’t? - Quora

response.answer_text: None of the existing models support 5G (unless you listen to AT&T tout a modest set of changes to LTE as “5G”, but that means “real 5G” on AT&T is going to get called something lame). That probably isn’t a big deal because 5G doesn’t bring much to most people. 5G is in theory faster then LTE, but guess what, LTE for most people isn’t as fast as LTE “really is”. You get to share the cells bandwidth with tons of other people, and the backhaul from the cells towers to elsewhere is frequently a bottleneck. The same will happen with 5G. I’m not saying 5G will be for sure the same speed as LTE, but in a lot of places it will. More over…what do you do on your phone that would be faster if the network ran faster? Wait, let me rephrase that. In places where your cell network is running at full speed and not constrained by bandwidth from the cell tower to the backbone, or on the server side, or anywhere from the server to your phone except the one the air LTE part…all of those times, how much difference would more speed make? That is what 5G can make better. Well, that is what “normal” 5G makes better. 5G has some optional parts for “super low bandwidth super low power” which if cell towers support it phones might use sometimes to make “standby” power last longer (or they may not, I think it requires antennas tuned to new frequency bands). 5G also has some tiny cell modes for high bandwidth “fixed wireless”, which in theory a phone could use, but again it is on different frequencies. I think it also omits doppler compensation (so you can’t move, or can’t move much while using this mode). These modes are useful, but more to non-phones then to phones. I mean, sure if everything else is equal getting 5G is better than not getting 5G. If everything else is actually equal (battery usage, heat generation, price). Currently it isn’t, and won’t be for a while. So I wouldn’t worry about 5G in phones for a while.

No iPhone supports 5g at present. And Apple has not revealed any plans how and when they intend to support 5G. If they do, it will be obvious that they will do that for all the iPhones that are released from a certain level on. Supporting 5G on a smartphone today really doesn't make a lot of sense. There is no broad support in terms of deployed networks. Unless you live in a neighborhood where 5G is already deployed, and 5g does give you the performance plus that you desperately need. Apple won't go down that route until it is a selling point for their products — which it isn't today.
